Trial_Design.evidence: Those undergoing off-pump CABG were randomized to a partial clamp (n=36) or clampless facilitating device (CFD, n=36) strategy.

Participants.evidence: 142 patients with low-grade aortic disease (epiaortic ultrasound grade I /II) undergoing primary isolated CABG were studied.

Intervention.evidence: Those undergoing off-pump CABG were randomized to a partial clamp (n=36) or clampless facilitating device (CFD, n=36) strategy.

Objective.evidence: The purpose of this study was to determine the impact of different aortic clamping strategies on the incidence of cerebral embolic events during coronary artery bypass grafting(CABG).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was total number of HITS detected by TCD.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Those undergoing off-pump CABG were randomized to a partial clamp (n=36) or clampless facilitating device (CFD, n=36) strategy.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From 2012–2015, 142 patients with low-grade aortic disease (epiaortic ultrasound grade I /II) undergoing primary isolated CABG were studied.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the off-pump group, median total HITS were higher in the CFD group (30.0, IQR 22–43) compared to the partial clamp group (7.0, IQR 0–16) (p<0.0001).

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the off-pump group, median total HITS were higher in the CFD group (30.0, IQR 22–43) compared to the partial clamp group (7.0, IQR 0–16) (p<0.0001).
